Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation, diabetes, and hypertension. He was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure and subsequent management. The patient has been mechanically ventilated since admission. Recent interventions include placement of an arterial line, bronchoscopy, and MRI/MRA.

The patient's current vital signs show a blood pressure of 147/49 mmHg, heart rate of 67 bpm, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on 40% FiO2. The patient is still hypernatremic with a sodium level of 149 mEq/L. Chest X-ray reveals moderate bilateral pleural effusions without enhancement and collapsed lower lobes of the lungs. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (450 K/uL), slightly low hemoglobin level (8.1 g/dL), elevated potassium level (5.4 mEq/L), and normal glucose levels. Other lab values are within normal limits.

The patient's condition continues to be complicated by respiratory failure, pericardial effusion without tamponade, dysphagia, ischemic stroke, atrial fibrillation, acute diastolic heart failure, and hypernatremia. The patient remains on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 4569**] is a 70 yo male with Type 2 DM, HTN, BPH, CHF, A. fib,
   admitted for tamponade, now s/p pericardial drain with PNA and possible
   CVA, and now transfered to the MICU for resp distress with incrased
   somulence requiring intubation.
   .
   # Hypercarbic resp failure: Patient more tachypnic and solumnolent
   (likely secondary to sedating medications). In addition he had
   increased mucus secretions and was at high risk for aspiration. Initial
   CXR showed a white out of his left lung, which may be secondary to
   mucus plugging. Pt is also being treated for an underlying PNA with
   zosyn, started [**1-10**]. At baseline the pt may have resp disease due to a
   long hx of tobacco use. New infection is possible, but pt has been
   afebrile and BP stable, so likely more an obstructive process. ABG
   improved to 7.32/62/119 after intubation. Bronch and blood/urine/sputum
   samples so far unrevealing. CT chest/abd cuts showed large pleural
   effusions
   - Consider IP consult or aggressive diuresis for pleural effusions
   (although likely overdiuresed, hypernatremic)
   - continue zosyn for now (Last day of 10 day course: [**2107-1-20**])
   - Hold further zyprexa and haldol
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium MDIs
   # Expressive aphasia/AM- Likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA per
   neuro. New worsening MS is concerning for either delerium vs new
   cerbral vascular event. No new focal findings, but pt was not
   cooperative with exam prior to intubation. MRI/MRA yesterday negative
   for acute processes so ?delirium/toxic metabolic as etiology for his
   symptoms
   - Appreciate neurology following
   - Restarting anticoagulation given subtherapeutic INR today and no
   acute intracranial bleed seen on MRI
   - BP control
   # Hypernatremia- Likely due to decreased free water intake in setting
   of dysphagia and lack of NGT and being on lasix. Free water deficit of
   ~1.5 liters today. Slightly improved from Na 151
 149. Received D5W at
   100/hr X1L after D5W with bicarb and 500cc of D5W in KCl repletion, D5W
   still running
   - PM lytes for correcting sodium
   .
   #. Dysphagia- Likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA. Pt likely
   aspirated last night, [**Last Name **] problem above. Pt has failed a swallow
   study.  Started tube feeds overnight
   - Discuss with GI vs. IR re: PEG tube placement now that INR
   subtherapeutic
   .
   #. A. fib/Bradycardia- new onset prior to OSH admission. Thought to be
   [**1-18**] his CHF and diuresis. Now in sinus. Seems to have runs of sinus
   brady as well as junctional rhythms. Has been anticoagulated due to
   recent cardioembolic stroke.
   - supratheraputic INR so holding coumadin
   - consider restarting dig if needed
   - will give PO dilt with OG tube
   # CHF: Diastolic HF, had been tx for last month with lasix. Now appears
   over diuresed due to hypernatremia.
   - Will continue gentle IVF to correct Na
   - Hold lasix for now
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Unclear etiology, cutlures were negative. Could
   have been viral or autoimmune. Pt has some renal failure, but not
   likely severe enough to develop efuusion [**1-18**] to this. Pt is now s/p
   pericardial drain. TSH was normal.
   - Monitor clinically for reaccumulation of pericardial effusion
   - Cardiology following
   .
   # DM2- On metformin at home.
   - ISS, follow fingersticks  especially on D5W
   .
   # HTN- Was on lopressor & nifedipine at home, then had been on
   amlodipine in-house when pt had prior PO access. BP now stable.
   Restarted amlodipine yesterday
   - Continue Diltiazem but consider decreasing dose (currently Dilt 60
   TID)
   # BPH/hematuria- Hematuria improving
   - Will need outpatient cystoscopy
   - Continue foley for now since intubated
   - Resume flomax prior to foley removal
   .
   # FEN: will start tube feeds today once done with [**Last Name (un) **], on D5W
   CODE: FULL, confirmed, wife is [**Name (NI) 3563**] number on consent in chart
   [**Name (NI) **]: supratheraputic INR
   Dispo: ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Tube feeds started after Bronch today
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale

 subtherapeutic today so

Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted for cardiac tamponade and underwent pericardial drainage. He is now experiencing respiratory distress and has been intubated. The patient also has hypercarbic respiratory failure, expressive aphasia, hypernatremia, dysphagia, atrial fibrillation with bradycardia, heart failure (diastolic), pericardial effusion, diabetes mellitus type 2, and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress and subsequent intubation indicate a potential complication of respiratory failure. It is important to monitor his oxygenation and ventilation parameters closely.
2. Pericardial Effusion: The patient had a pericardial effusion, which required drainage. Monitoring for reaccumulation of the effusion is crucial.
3. Dysphagia: The patient's dysphagia may increase the risk of aspiration pneumonia. Ensuring proper airway protection and feeding techniques are essential.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, indicating hypernatremia. Close monitoring and appropriate fluid management are necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Cerebrovascular Accident (Stroke): The patient's expressive aphasia and potential

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's ABG showed a low pH indicating respiratory acidosis, which suggests hypoventilation leading to increased CO2 levels in the blood.

3. Expressive aphasia/AM: The patient has expressive aphasia and altered mental status, likely secondary to a cardioembolic CVA. Further evaluation by neurology is recommended.
4. Bradycardia: The patient has a history of bradycardia, which may be related to his CHF and diuretic use. Atropine has been ordered at the bedside.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient has high sodium levels, likely due to decreased free water intake, dysphagia, and diuretic use. Free water deficit is being corrected with D5W.

Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted for cardiac tamponade, now post-pericardial drain, with pneumonia and possible cerebrovascular accident (CVA). He is currently in the medical intensive care unit (MICU) due to respiratory distress and increased somnolence requiring intubation. The patient has hypercarbic respiratory failure, dysphagia, acute stroke, atrial fibrillation, diastolic heart failure, hypernatremia, pericardial effusion without tamponade, and acute respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern, as indicated by his hypercarbic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress. There is a risk of further respiratory failure if the pleural effusions recur or if there is a new infection.
2. Stroke: The patient has had a cerebrovascular accident (CVA), which has resulted in expressive aphasia and possible worsening mini-mental state (MS). There is a potential for another stroke due to the presence of atrial fibrillation and the patient's underlying cardiovascular conditions.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation needs to be managed to prevent further complications such as thromboembolic events.

He was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) with pneumonia, large bilateral pleural effusions, possible cerebrovascular accident (CVA), and respiratory distress requiring intubation.

The patient's condition has been fluctuating. Initially, he was doing well on CPAP/PSV but then developed hypercarbic respiratory failure and was placed back on the ventilator. A thoracentesis was performed, revealing exudates in the pleural fluid. The patient's ABG showed a low pH level, indicating respiratory acidosis. The chest X-ray revealed right lower lobe haziness, suggesting possible pneumonia or fluid accumulation.

The patient's white blood cell count has been increasing, indicating a possible infection. He was restarted on antibiotics, but his sputum culture results are pending. The patient's renal function tests are abnormal, showing elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels. His liver function tests are also abnormal, with elevated liver enzymes.

   - Appreciate neurology following

   - BP control
   #. A. fib/Bradycardia- new onset prior to OSH admission. Thought to be

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and chronic kidney disease. He was admitted for cardiac tamponade, which has since been managed with pericardial drainage. The patient is now in the MICU for respiratory distress and possible cerebrovascular accident (CVA), likely due to a cardioembolic stroke.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has improved after intubation and ventilation. Initial chest X-ray showed whiteout of his left lung, possibly due to mucus plugging, which has since improved. The patient is being treated for pneumonia with Zosyn.

2. Expressive aphasia: The patient is likely experiencing expressive aphasia secondary to a cardioembolic CVA. New worsening of his mental status is concerning for either delirium or a new cerebral vascular event. An MRI/MRA yesterday was negative for acute processes.

3. Atrial fibrillation/Bradycardia: The patient has new-onset atrial fibrillation with bradycardia, likely secondary to heart failure and diuresis. This has since resolved into sinus rhythm with occasional runs of sinus bradycardia and junctional rhythms.

4. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia likely due to decreased free water

Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted for cardiac tamponade and underwent a pericardial drain. The patient also has pneumonia and a possible cerebrovascular accident (stroke).

Assessment and plan:
1. Pleural effusion, acute
2. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
3. Pericardial effusion (without tamponade)
4. Dysphagia
5. CVA (stroke), ischemic
6. Atrial fibrillation (AFib)
7. Heart failure (CHF), diastolic, acute
8. Hypernatremia (high sodium)

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, reaccumulation of pericardial effusion, further neurological decline, electrolyte imbalances, and possible infections. It is crucial to continue with aggressive supportive care, including ongoing respiratory support, fluid management, and close monitoring of vital signs, electrolytes, and neurologic status.

   which may be secondary to mucus plugging that has since improved on
   ventilation. Pt is also being treated for an underlying PNA with zosyn,
   started [**1-10**]. At baseline the pt may have resp disease due to a long hx

   - Thoracentesis for pleural effusion management and diagnosis

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with multiple medical conditions, including type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2), hypertension (HTN), benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), congestive heart failure (CHF), and atrial fibrillation (AFib). He was admitted for cardiac tamponade and underwent pericardial drain. He also has pneumonia (PNA) and possible cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The patient required intubation due to respiratory distress and increased somnolence.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Pleural effusion, acute: Thoracentesis for management and diagnosis.
2. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS): Continue ventilatory support.
3. Pericardial effusion (without tamponade): Monitor clinically for reaccumulation.
4. Dysphagia: Discuss with dietitian regarding possible percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement.
5. Hypernatremia: Administer D5W and monitor electrolytes.
6. CHF, diastolic: Hold Lasix and continue to monitor clinically.
7. Atrial fibrillation/bradycardia: Follow-up cardiology recommendations regarding heart rate management.
8. BPH/hematuria: Schedule outpatient cystoscopy and resume flomax prior to foley removal.
9. Fever: Monitor temperature and investigate potential sources of infection.
10. Delir

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and recent pericardial drain for idiopathic effusion. He was admitted to the MICU with pneumonia, large bilateral pleural effusions, possible cerebrovascular accident, and respiratory distress requiring intubation.

Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient had been doing well on CPAP/PSV but required mechanical ventilation due to a downward trending minute volume and an ABG of 7.22/85/117. A repeat ABG was 7.38/58/133.
2. Expressive aphasia/Altered mental status: Likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA per neuro. MRI/MRA negative for acute processes.
3. Atrial fibrillation/Bradycardia: The patient had frequent PVCs and bradycardias after discontinuing Diltiazem.
4. Hypernatremia: Corrected with D5W and electrolyte management.
5. Dysphagia: Failed a swallow study, and a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube was placed.
6. Pericardial effusion: Unclear etiology, cultures were negative.
7. Diabetes mellitus type 2: On metformin at home, and monitoring fingersticks especially on D5W.
8.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and possible cerebrovascular accident. He was admitted to the MICU with pneumonia, large bilateral pleural effusions, and respiratory distress requiring intubation. 

The patient has been on mechanical ventilation with assist control mode since January 21st due to worsening hypercarbic respiratory failure. His condition has shown some improvement with improvement in chest X-ray findings. 

The patient's white blood cell count has fluctuated but is now back to baseline. He has been weaned off Zosyn, an antibiotic, as his sputum culture came back negative. Rheumatology labs are pending for further evaluation.

The patient's blood pressure and heart rate have been stable, but he experienced episodes of bradycardia and atrial fibrillation. His coagulation status is being managed with heparin, and he will be bridged to coumadin soon.

The patient has hypernatremia, which was addressed by administering D5W at 100 cc/hr and potassium repletion. Lasix diuresis is planned to resume once his electrolytes are within normal range.

The patient has dysphagia likely due to a cardioembolic stroke. A swallow study was failed, and he required a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement for nutrition.

His pericardial effusion remains unclear in etiology, and cultures were negative. Cardiology recommendations were not pursued further.

The patient's other medical conditions include diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and hematuria. 

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure has been recurrent, and he required intubation. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and further deterioration in respiratory function.

2. Pleural Effusion: The patient has large bilateral pleural effusions. If the effusions reaccumulate or do not improve with current management, thoracentesis may be necessary, which carries its own risks.

3. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which requires careful management to avoid complications such as dehydration or osmotic demyelination syndrome.

4. Dysphagia: The patient's dysphagia secondary to a possible cardioembolic stroke can lead to aspiration pneumonia or malnutrition if proper nutrition support is not provided.

5. Pericardial Effusion: Although the patient's pericardial effusion appears to be stable for now, there is a risk of reaccumulation or development of cardiac tamponade if the effusion worsens.

6. Cardiovascular Events: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and possible cerebrovascular accident increases the risk of future cardiovascular events such as stroke or arrhythmias.

7. Infection: Despite negative cultures, the patient initially presented with pneumonia, and there is a risk of recurrent infections, especially with prolonged intubation and immunosuppression.

8. Delirium or Metabolic Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status may be due to delirium, metabolic encephal

Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for the patient. These include:

1. Pleural effusion: The patient has large bilateral pleural effusions, which can lead to respiratory distress and compromise lung function.

2. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient initially did well on CPAP/PSV but later required intubation due to increased somnolence and a downward trending minute volume. This indicates possible hypercarbic respiratory failure.

3. Possible CVA (Cerebrovascular Accident) or stroke: The patient has expressive aphasia and altered mental status, which could be secondary to a cardioembolic stroke. Further evaluation is needed to confirm this.

4. Bradycardia and tachy-brady syndrome: The patient experienced frequent PVCs (premature ventricular contractions) and bradycardia after discontinuing Diltiazem. This may indicate tachy-brady syndrome, which is a combination of fast and slow heart rhythms.

5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels were elevated, requiring careful management with IV fluids to prevent complications like cerebral edema.

6. Dysphagia: The patient likely has dysphagia secondary to a cardioembolic CVA. This can lead to aspiration pneumonia if not managed properly.

7. Pericardial effusion: The patient had an idiopathic pericardial effusion that required drainage. The etiology

Summary:
The patient is a 67-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure secondary to an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was intubated upon admission due to hypoxemia and subsequent ventilatory failure. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, dysphagia, hypernatremia, pericardial effusion, and pleural effusion. 

During the 24-hour period, the patient underwent thoracentesis, which revealed an exudative pleural effusion. The pleural fluid analysis showed elevated protein, glucose, LDH, and WBC count, indicating an inflammatory process. The patient's pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio was 0.71, suggesting exudation. 

A percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube was placed without complications, and the patient is expected to start tube feeding tomorrow. The patient's condition has been stable, with improving respiratory status as evidenced by decreased oxygen requirements and weaning off ventilatory support. 

The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a slightly elevated sodium level. His renal function is normal, and liver enzymes are within normal limits. 

The patient's blood cultures were negative for any infections. The patient's INR was elevated, which precluded the placement of a gastrointestinal peg. However, once the INR normalizes, the patient will be started on anticoagulation therapy

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a [age]-year-old [gender] admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to aspiration. They have a history of pneumonia and are currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient is intubated and unresponsive, with decreased breath sounds in the lungs. There is evidence of fluid overload, as indicated by the trace edema and positive fluid balance. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, and normal platelet count. There is also evidence of hypernatremia. Imaging reveals large effusions in the chest. The patient has been diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, acute pleural effusion, pericardial effusion without tamponade, and atrial fibrillation. They are currently being treated with IV heparin and antibiotics, and efforts are being made to diurese the pleural effusion. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The prolonged use of mechanical ventilation increases the risk of developing pneumonia. Close monitoring for symptoms such as fever, increased white blood cell count, and changes in sputum color or odor is essential.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and central venous catheters increase the risk of blood clots forming in the deep veins. Regular monitoring for signs of DVT, such as leg swelling or pain, and the use of prophylactic heparin are important preventive measures.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is significantly low, which can compromise organ perfusion. Continuous monitoring and appropriate fluid management are crucial to maintain adequate blood pressure.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's high sodium levels may lead to neurological complications if not properly managed. Close attention to fluid balance and electrolyte management is necessary.
5. Pericardial effusion: Although currently without tamponade, the presence of fluid around the heart increases the risk of cardiac tamponade. Close monitoring of cardiac function and echocardiograms will be necessary to detect any worsening of the effusion.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a [**Female First Name (un)**] with a chief complaint of respiratory failure due to suspected aspiration. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. Her past medical history, social history, and review of systems remain unchanged from admission except where noted above and below.

24-hour events:
The patient received a dose of piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) at 08:00 AM on [**2107-1-22**]. She is currently receiving heparin sodium at a rate of 1,450 units/hour and propofol at 30 mcg/kg/min. Other ICU medications include unspecified others.

Physical examination:
The patient is intubated and arousable but not following commands. Her lungs show decreased breath sounds bilaterally, with a heart rhythm of sinus rhythm and loud S2. Her abdomen is benign with a gastrostomy tube in place. She has extreme trace edema.

Lab results:
Her blood tests reveal a hemoglobin level of 8.0 g/dL, leukocyte count of 13.4 K/uL, platelet count of 515, and creatinine level of 0.7 mg/dL. Her electrolytes show sodium at 147 mg/dL, potassium at 3.9 mEq/L, chloride at 112 mEq/L, bicarbonate at 24.4%, magnesium at 0.7 mg/dL, and calcium at 8.4 mg/dL. Other lab results include elevated lactic acid, LDH, and slightly elevated glucose levels.

Radiology:
A chest X-ray shows large effusions in a supine position.

Assessment and plan:
1. PLEURAL EFFUSION, ACUTE: The plan is to attempt diuresis, and if unsuccessful, perform bilateral thoracentesis.
2. RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): Once the patient starts to diurese or after [**Last Name (LF)**], [**First Name3 (LF)**] do a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT).
3. PERICARDIAL EFFUSION (WITHOUT TAMPONADE): Recent echo showed recovery of EF and no recurrence of effusion.
4. ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB) /? atrial thrombus: Continue heparin, eventual conversion to coumadin.
5. HYPERNATREMIA (HIGH SODIUM): Follow and continue hydration.
6. ICU Care:
   - Nutrition: NPO for possible extubation.
   - Glycemic control.
   - Lines: Arterial line placed on [**2107-1-19**] at 12:00 PM, 20 gauge placed on [**2107-1-19**] at 01:12 PM, and PICC line placed on [**2107-1-20**] at 09:00 AM.
   - Prophylaxis: DVT on IV heparin.
   - Stress ulcer prophylaxis.
   - Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prophylaxis.
   - Code status: Full code.
   - Disposition: ICU.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and previous pericardial drain for idiopathic effusion. The patient was admitted to the MICU with pneumonia, large bilateral pleural effusions, and possible cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The patient experienced respiratory distress requiring intubation.

The patient's current medical complications include:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient had been doing well and was successfully extubated, but overnight became hypertensive, increased work of breathing, diaphoretic, and found to be in respiratory acidosis/hypercarbia. The patient was reintubated.
2. Expressive aphasia/AMS: The patient is likely experiencing cardioembolic CVA. An MRI/MRA was negative for acute processes, so the etiology could be delirium/toxic/metabolic in addition to cardioembolic stroke.
3. Atrial fibrillation/Bradycardia: The patient had frequent PVCs and bradys, but no more episodes in the last 24 hours. The patient will continue anticoagulation with heparin gtt and may need to be bridged to coumadin for long-term anticoagulation.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels have been stable between 145-147. The patient is receiving free water

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and possible cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The patient was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) due to pneumonia, large bilateral pleural effusions, and respiratory distress requiring intubation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient had a previous episode of respiratory distress that led to reintubation. The etiology for this repeat episode is unclear but may be related to significant ongoing pleural effusions, agitation, hypertension, and possible flash pulmonary edema.

2. Expressive aphasia/AMS: The patient exhibits expressive aphasia and altered mental status (AMS), likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA. An MRI/MRA ruled out acute processes, leaving delirium, toxic/metabolic causes, or cardioembolic stroke as potential etiologies.

3. Atrial fibrillation/bradycardia: The patient presented with tachy-brady syndrome, which included frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) and bradycardia. This condition resolved after discontinuing standing diltiazem per cardiology recommendations.

4. Dysphagia: The patient likely developed dysphagia due to a cardioembolic CVA. A swallow study failed, and a percutaneous endoscopic gastro

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a well-nourished individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient required invasive ventilation support on 01/22/2107 at 05:21 PM and was weaned off it on 01/23/2107 at 04:06 AM.

The patient has been receiving multiple medications including furosemide, heparin sodium, propofol, lansoprazole, metoprolol, and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below.

The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.9C (98.5F), heart rate of 48 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 119/43(62) mmHg to 199/87(128) mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus bradycardia.

The patient has been receiving mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 550 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) values indicate a pH of 7.52, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 168 mmHg, and bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 36 mEq/L.

Physical examination reveals no notable findings in the head, ears, nose, throat, cardiovascular system, peripheral vascular system, or extremities. However, the patient has symmetric breath sounds in the chest and soft, non-tender abdomen with bowel sounds present. The patient's neurologic examination is not assessed due to sedation.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell (WBC) count ranging from 8.3 to 10.7 thousand/mm3, hematocrit (Hct) ranging from 23.7% to 28.2%, platelet (Plt) count ranging from 321 to 349 thousand/mm3, creatinine (Cr) level ranging from 0.6 to 0.7 mg/dL, and blood glucose level ranging from 82 to 128 mg/dL. Other lab values are within normal limits.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient has acute respiratory failure, not ARDS, pericardial effusion without tamponade, pleural effusion, dysphagia, atrial fibrillation (AFib), and hypernatremia (high sodium).

ICU care includes nutrition, glycemic control, arterial and peripheral IV lines, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is not mentioned.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 50-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient required intubation and mechanical ventilation due to agitation and hypertension leading to pulmonary edema. A chest X-ray revealed diffuse infiltrates consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, potassium, and sodium, indicating possible kidney dysfunction. The patient also has anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.9 g/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The prolonged use of mechanical ventilation increases the risk of developing pneumonia. Close monitoring for signs of infection, such as fever, increased white blood cell count, and productive cough, should be done.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Prolonged immobility and the presence of central venous catheters increase the risk of blood clots forming in the legs. Regular assessment for symptoms like swelling, pain, and redness in the lower extremities is important. Prophylactic heparin is being administered.
3. Stress ulcers: Critical illness can lead to stress ulcers in the stomach or duodenum. Prophylactic use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is recommended to prevent these ulcers.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium level needs to be closely monitored and managed to prevent

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient in the ICU is experiencing several health issues. The patient is agitated and hypertensive, with a blood pressure reading of 7.21/81/93. They were re-intubated 10 hours post-extubation. The patient has been receiving invasive ventilation, with the mode being CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow. The FiO2 is set at 50%, PEEP at 5 cmH2O, and RR (set) at 16. The ABG results indicate a pH of 7.52, PaCO2 of 36, and HCO3- of 84. The patient's physical examination shows a heart rhythm of SB (Sinus Bradycardia) with a heart rate of 57 bpm.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: Tcurrent: 36.2 C, HR: 57 bpm, BP: 156/52 mmHg, RR: 16 inspiratory minutes, and SpO2: 100%. The patient has received various medications, including Furosemide (Lasix), Heparin Sodium, and Propofol. The patient's last dose of antibiotics was Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) on 01-22-2107 at 08:00 AM.

The patient's labs show a WBC count of 8.3, Hct of 24.4, Plt of 348, Cr of 0.7, TCO2 of 34, Glucose of 115, and other lab values within normal ranges. The CXR reveals diffuse infiltrates. The assessment and plan include PLEURAL EFFUSION, ACUTE; RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (not ARDS); PERICARDIAL EFFUSION (without tamponade); ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB); HYPERNATREMIA (high sodium).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pleural effusion: This can lead to respiratory distress and decreased oxygenation if not managed properly.
2. Acute respiratory failure: If the patient's respiratory function continues to deteriorate, it can result in hypoxemia and subsequent organ damage.
3. Pericardial effusion: Although currently without tamponade, there is a risk of developing cardiac tamponade, which can be life-threatening if not addressed promptly.
4. Atrial fibrillation: This arrhythmia can increase the risk of thrombus formation and potential embolic events.
5. Hypernatremia: Elevated sodium levels can lead to neurological complications and dehydration.

Please note that the information provided in the progress note is based on the given data and does not include any additional details or follow-up information.

   Assessment and Plan
   70M with Type 2 DM, HTN, CHF, AF, s/p pericardial drain for idiopathic
   effusion, admitted to MICU with PNA, large bilateral pleural effusions,
   possible CVA, resp distress with incrased somulence requiring
   intubation.
   .
   # Hypercarbic resp failure: Had been doing well yesterday and weaned to
   Pressure Support 5, PEEP 5. Sedation turned off and patient extubated
   without issues. Overnight, however, became progressively hypertensive,
   increased work of breathing/diaphoretic and found to be in respiratory
   acidosis/hypercarbia. Reintubated ~10 hours after extubation at 3-4am.
   * Etiology for repeat episode of respiratory distress unclear but
   likely due to significant, ongoing pleural effusions in the setting of
   agitation, hypertension leading to possible flash pulmonary edema.
   - Will aggressively diurese today with Lasix gtt, goal -2L (until
   Creatinine bumps)
   - If insufficient diuresis of pleural effusions, will consider
   therapeutic bilateral thoracenteses
   - With next extubation, will attempt to keep patient calm/oriented and
   aggressively control blood pressures with IV nitroglycerin/hydralazine
   as needed to prevent flash pulmonary edema
   - Follow-up rheum labs
 [**Doctor First Name **] positive, titer still pending this morning
   - Follow-up sputum culture; gram stain negative
   - If cultures remain negative, may consider steroids since pericardial
   and parapneumonic effusions consistent with exudative process (could be
   collagen vascular disease vs. lung infection vs. malignancy vs. PE)
   .
   # Expressive aphasia/AMS- Likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA per
   neuro. MRI/MRA negative for acute processes so ?delirium/toxic
   metabolic in addition to cardioembolic stroke as etiology.
   - Back on Heparin gtt with normal PTT goals for now
   - Blood pressure control
   #. AF / Bradycardia- Looks like tachy-brady syndrome. After D/c
   standing Dilt per cards recs, patient had frequent PVCs and bradys to
   40s and 30s, but no more episodes in the last 48 hours. (Prior bradys
   had been seen as possibly vagal w/ETT).
   - Continue anticoagulation with heparin gtt per above
 eventual bridge
   to coumadin will be needed
   - EP f/u once stable for ablation +/- pacer
   - Atropine and pacer pads at bedside
   # Hypernatremia- Stable in the 145-147 range
   - Patient receiving free water with flushes for PEG tube feeds; will
   increase today in setting of slightly elevated serum sodium
   - PM lytes given ongoing Lasix diuresis
   .
   #. Dysphagia- Likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA. Failed a swallow
   study; PEG placed and was used starting yesterday
   - Continuing heparin gtt for now
   # Pericardial effusion: Unclear etiology, cultures were negative.
   - Monitor clinically for reaccumulation
   - Cardiology: no further recs
   .
   # DM2- On metformin at home.
   - ISS, follow fingersticks
   .
   # HTN- Continue amlodipine
   # BPH/hematuria- Hematuria resolved
   - Will need outpatient cystoscopy
   - Continue foley for now since re-intubated
   - Resume flomax prior to foley removal
   # FEN: PEG tube feeds, replete electrolytes PRN
   CODE: FULL, confirmed, wife is [**Name (NI) 3563**] number on consent in chart

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, Hypertension, Congestive Heart Failure, Atrial Fibrillation, and previous pericardial drain for idiopathic effusion. He was admitted to the MICU with pneumonia, large bilateral pleural effusions, possible CVA, and respiratory distress requiring intubation.

24-hour events include:
- Sputum culture pending
- EBV and CMV tests pending
- Hypertensive blood pressure readings
- Reintubation due to hypercarbic respiratory failure and agitation
- Diuretics prescribed to manage pleural effusions
- Possible flash pulmonary edema
- Follow-up rheum labs ordered
- Gram stain negative for sputum culture
- Steroids considered if cultures remain negative
- Expressive aphasia/AMS likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA
- Heparin gtt continued for now
- Blood pressure control remains a concern
- Atrial fibrillation with bradycardia (tachy-brady syndrome)
- Frequent PVCs and bradys resolved after discontinuation of Dilt
- Anticoagulation with heparin gtt recommended
- Hypernatremia stable in the range of 145-147
- Dysphagia likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA
- PEG tube placed due to failed swallow study
- Heparin

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He presented to the ICU with pericardial and pulmonary effusions, unclear etiology. The patient had a previous episode of respiratory distress that required intubation, but was successfully extubated. However, overnight, he became hypertensive, increased work of breathing, diaphoretic, and developed respiratory acidosis/hypercarbia, leading to reintubation. The patient's current condition includes expressive aphasia/AMS, possible cardioembolic CVA, and hypernatremia. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's repeat episode of respiratory distress could be due to ongoing pleural effusions, agitation, hypertension leading to flash pulmonary edema, and inadequate diuresis. Aggressive diuresis with Lasix gtt and consideration of therapeutic bilateral thoracenteses may be necessary.
2. Cardioembolic CVA: The patient's expressive aphasia/AMS could be secondary to a cardioembolic stroke. Further follow-up with neurology is recommended.
3. Tachy-brady syndrome: The patient had frequent PVCs and bradys after discontinuation of Dilt, but no recent episodes have been observed. Anticoagulation with heparin gtt and consideration of bridging to coumadin for long

Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of diabetes, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation who was admitted to the ICU for pericardial and pulmonary effusions. He was extubated but then reintubated due to hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including hypercarbic respiratory failure, bilateral pulmonary effusions, pericardial effusion, expressive aphasia, hypernatremia, atrial fibrillation with bradycardia, dysphagia, and a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia with hematuria, and a feeding tube.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's previous episode of respiratory distress indicates the potential for recurrent respiratory failure.
2. Bilateral pulmonary effusions: The presence of chronic and poorly explained bilateral pulmonary effusions suggests a possible underlying condition that could lead to further complications.
3. Pericardial effusion: Although the patient's pericardial effusion is currently stable, it may worsen or develop complications such as cardiac tamponade.
4. Expressive aphasia: The patient's inability to speak fluently may impact communication and increase the risk of complications related to inadequate information exchange.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's high sodium levels could indicate a disturbance in fluid balance, potentially leading to further electrolyte imbalances.

He is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate set at 16 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%, and plateau pressure of 16 cmH2O. His vital signs include a temperature of 37.5C, heart rate of 70 bpm, blood pressure of 115/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient has been receiving heparin sodium infusion, furosemide (Lasix) infusion, and propofol sedation. His labs show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin level, elevated blood glucose levels, and normal kidney function. The patient's recent EBV serologies indicate a past infection. Thoracentesis was deferred until tomorrow. The patient's overall condition remains stable with ongoing lasix therapy to manage fluid balance.

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation for an extended

   Assessment and Plan
   70M DM CHF AF p/w pericardial (drained) and pulmonary (diuresing)
   effusions, unclear etiologies, extubated then intubated for hypercarbic
   respiratory failure
   .
   # Hypercarbic resp failure: Etiology for repeat episode of respiratory
   distress unclear. Occurred in setting of these chronically and still
   poorly explained bilateral pulmonary effusions. Tired quickly on
   pressure support yesterday, ECHO unchanged from prior.
   - Continue Lasix gtt for attempted diuresis
   - Will discuss with Interventional Pulmonary pleural effusion removal
   options which should help with extubation and maintaining
   self-ventilation
   # Bilateral pulmonary effusions: Likely one process driving both the
   pericardial and pulmonary effusions. [**Doctor First Name **] positive but titer 1:80,
   speckled likely non-specific
   - Consult Rheumatology
   - Discuss with IP per above (therapeutic thoracentesis vs. drain
   placement)
   - CT chest after therapeutic [**Female First Name (un) 217**] or sufficient drainage to assess
   size of effusions
   - Continue Lasix gtt per above although decreasing urine output to
   Lasix and systolic blood pressures low yesterday
   # Hypernatremia: Working hypothesis is this resulted from earlier fluid
   management decisions. Now resolved
   - Decrease free water with tube feeds
   # Expressive Aphasia: In setting of runs of A Fib, with known atrial
   thrombus, and MRI/MRA showing sequelae of cardioembolic strokes.
   - On Heparin gtt, PTT 52.6
   - Good blood pressure control
   #. AF / Bradycardia: Has been in sinus rhythm for past two days. Note
   thrombus in atrium.
   - Continue anticoagulation with Heparin gtt -- eventual bridge to
   Coumadin
   - EP f/u once stable for ablation +/- pacer
   - Atropine and pacer pads at bedside
   #. Dysphagia- Likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA. Failed a swallow
   study.
   - PEG tube feeds
   # Pericardial effusion: Unclear etiology, cultures were negative.  ECHO
   yesterday showed stable, minimal pericardial effusions
   # DM2- On metformin at home.
   - ISS, follow fingersticks
   .
   # HTN- Continue amlodipine and home lopressor
   - Will consider adding Captopril as needed
   # BPH/hematuria- Hematuria resolved
   - Outpatient cystoscopy
   - Continue Foley while intubated
   - Resume Flomax prior to Foley removal
   # FEN: PEG tube feeds, replete electrolytes PRN

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He presented to the ICU with pericardial and pulmonary effusions of unclear etiology. The patient was extubated and then reintubated due to hypercarbic respiratory failure. He has been diagnosed with expressive aphasia, likely secondary to cardioembolic strokes. Other medical conditions include dysphagia, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia with hematuria, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's initial respiratory failure required intubation and mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of recurrent respiratory failure if the effusions recur or worsen.
2. Stroke: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of atrial thrombus increase the risk of stroke. The patient has already experienced cardioembolic strokes causing expressive aphasia.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and comorbidities increase the risk of DVT. Anticoagulation therapy is being administered to prevent thrombus formation.
4. Infection: The patient has developed fever and elevated inflammatory markers, suggesting a possible infection. Close monitoring for signs of infection is essential.
5. Cardiac Dysfunction: The patient's history of congestive heart failure may predispose him to worsening cardiac function. Close monitoring of fluid

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of diabetes, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted with pericardial and pulmonary effusions of unclear etiology, extubated, then reintubated for hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient's respiratory status has improved, with plans to attempt pressure support, spontaneous breathing trial (SBT), and potential extubation tomorrow. 

The patient's pleural effusion was drained, and cultures were negative. An echocardiogram showed minimal pericardial effusion. He also has dysphagia likely secondary to a cardioembolic stroke. 

The patient's atrial fibrillation has resolved, and he has a known atrial thrombus. He is on heparin and will be bridged to Coumadin. 

The patient has hypernatremia, which was resolved by adjusting fluid management. He also has expressive aphasia, possibly related to his runs of atrial fibrillation and known atrial thrombus. 

The patient has multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia with hematuria, and familial dyslexia. 

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pleural effusion: The patient has had an acute respiratory failure and a pleural effusion. This could potentially lead to further respiratory compromise if not managed appropriately.

2. Pericardial eff

Summary:
The patient is a [age]-year-old [gender] admitted to the ICU for evaluation and management of respiratory failure, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, hypotension, and hypernatremia. The patient underwent thoracentesis on [date] and had a mildly exudative pleural fluid with a LDH level of 127. The patient's condition has been unstable, with episodes of tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension requiring interventions such as a bolus of fluids and holding lasix. The patient is currently on pressure support and ABG analysis shows a pH of 7.53, PaCO2 of 43, PaO2 of 151, HCO3- of 34, and BE of -12. Other notable findings include fever, elevated white blood cell count, elevated lactate levels, and elevated troponin T levels. The patient is also experiencing dysphagia and atrial fibrillation. The patient's blood pressure is currently stable, but there are concerns about the potential complications arising from the pleural effusion and pericardial effusion. The patient's sodium levels are elevated, indicating hypernatremia. The patient is receiving nutritional support through Boost Glucose Control and is on multiple medications including heparin sodium, lasix, and others. The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is unknown.

   Assessment and Plan
   70M DM CHF AF p/w pericardial (drained) and pulmonary (diuresing)
   effusions, unclear etiologies, extubated then intubated for hypercarbic
   respiratory failure
   .
   # Respiratory status: Good looking CXR after thoracentesis X2. Etiology
   of respiratory problems likely the effusions, which could be
   rheumatologic or represent fluid overload. Of note he is 3.7 L + for
   LOS, and despite great UOP he is basically even for fluid balance not
   counting the thoracentesis. The effusions could be rheumatologic,
   although the [**Doctor First Name **] positive but titer 1:80, speckled likely non-specific.
   Sed rate and CRP markedly elevated. Rheumatology does not feel strongly
   that patient
s effusions are caused by underlying connective tissue
   disease
   - Although tired after three hours on pressure support yesterday, doing
   well this morning. Will try to extubate today. If fails again, would
   consider tracheostomy
   - Hold on further Lasix gtt diuresis given low blood pressures
   overnight
   - Will order repeat CT chest
   # Expressive Aphasia: In setting of runs of A Fib, with known atrial
   thrombus, and MRI/MRA showing sequelae of cardioembolic strokes.
   - On Heparin gtt
   - Good blood pressure control
   # Mild leukocytosis: Could be due to demargination from thoracenteses
   vs. underlying infectious/malignant/rheum process
   - Will trend for now
   - Monitor fever curve
   #. AF / Bradycardia: Has been in sinus rhythm for past 3 days. Note
   thrombus in atrium.
   - Continue anticoagulation with Heparin gtt -- eventual bridge to
   Coumadin
   - EP f/u once stable for ablation +/- pacer, if needed
   - Atropine and pacer pads at bedside
   - On Amlodipine and home lopressor for now
   #. Dysphagia- Likely secondary to cardioembolic CVA. Failed a swallow
   study.
   - PEG tube feeds
   # Pericardial effusion: Unclear etiology, cultures were negative.
   Recent Echo showed stable, minimal pericardial effusions
   # DM2- On metformin at home.
   - ISS, follow fingersticks
   .
   # HTN- Continue amlodipine and home lopressor
   - Will consider adding Captopril as needed but blood pressures low
   overnight
   # BPH/hematuria- Hematuria resumed overnight but mild
   - Outpatient cystoscopy
   - Continue Foley while intubated
   - Resume Flomax prior to Foley removal
   # FEN: PEG tube feeds, replete electrolytes PRN

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus (DM), congestive heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (AF), pericardial and pulmonary effusions, dysphagia, hypertension (HTN), benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) with hematuria, and type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2). The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for various complications.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the given information include:

1. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing low blood pressure, which may lead to inadequate tissue perfusion and organ dysfunction.

2. Pleural effusion, acute: The patient has had pleural fluid drained through thoracentesis. This suggests an underlying condition causing fluid accumulation in the pleural space.

3. Respiratory failure, acute: The patient initially required intubation due to hypercarbic respiratory failure. There is a possibility of recurrent respiratory failure if the effusions are not adequately managed.

4. Pericardial effusion: Although the recent echo showed stable and minimal pericardial effusions, there is still a risk of recurrent effusion development or cardiac tamponade if not properly managed.

5. Dysphagia: The patient has expressive aphasia and dysphagia, likely secondary to a cardioembolic stroke. This can lead to aspiration pneumonia and malnutrition if proper feeding

   .

   and despite good UOP he is basically even for fluid balance not
   counting the thoracentesis. The effusions could be rheumatologic,
   although the [**Doctor First Name **] positive but titer 1:80, speckled likely non-specific.
   Sed rate and CRP markedly elevated. Rheumatology does not feel strongly
   that patient
s effusions are caused by underlying connective tissue
   disease but can not rule out drug induced SLE. Most likely this was a
   viral syndrome. Repeat CT chest yesterday not suggestive of infection,
   malignancy, reaccumulation of pleural fluid.  Ultimately, patient
   likely has emphysema and chronic mild hypercarbia which should be
   followed-up as outpatient.
   - Although tired after three hours on pressure support previously,
   patient has been tolerating extubation well. If fails again, would
   consider tracheostomy
   - Hold on further Lasix gtt diuresis given low blood pressures
   overnight
   - Will wean nasal cannula as tolerated
   .
   # Expressive Aphasia: In setting of runs of A Fib, with known atrial
   thrombus, and MRI/MRA showing sequelae of cardioembolic strokes.
   - On Heparin gtt; start Coumadin today
   - Good blood pressure control

   vs. underlying infectious/malignant/rheum process
   - Will trend for now
   - Monitor fever curve
   #. AF / Bradycardia: Has been in sinus rhythm for past 4 days. Note
   thrombus in atrium.
   - Continue anticoagulation with Heparin gtt
 will start bridging to

   - EP f/u once stable for ablation +/- pacer, if needed
   - Atropine and pacer pads at bedside
   - On Amlodipine and home lopressor for now

   study.
   - PEG tube feeds
   # Pericardial effusion: Unclear etiology, cultures were negative.
   Recent Echo showed stable, minimal pericardial effusions.  Patient does
   have significant cardiomegaly on CT chest and chest xrays
 with
   previously read EF65%, patient likely has MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 13277**] EF.
   - Will repeat ECHO today given possibly better windows with removal of

   - ISS, follow fingersticks

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of diabetes, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU for pericardial and pulmonary effusions, unclear etiology, and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient has been extubated and re-intubated multiple times. He has been tolerating extubation well but may require a tracheostomy if it fails again. The patient's pleural effusions have improved, and there are no signs of infection or malignancy. His cardiac function is compromised, with a history of a thrombus in the atrium and evidence of cardioembolic strokes. He is currently in sinus rhythm but requires anticoagulation with heparin and will start bridging to Coumadin today. The patient also has mild leukocytosis, dysphagia, and mild hypernatremia. He has a history of hypertension, benign hypotension, acute pleural effusion, acute respiratory failure, pericardial effusion without tamponade, and atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still a concern, as evidenced by previous episodes of hypercarbic respiratory failure. If the patient's lungs do not recover adequately, there is a risk of further respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, with a history of congestive heart failure

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure and had pericardial and pulmonary effusions that were drained. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His blood pressure has been fluctuating, with episodes of hypertension and hypotension. He also has leukocytosis, dysphagia, hypernatremia, and a history of benign hypertension and hypotension. The patient's current medications include metoprolol, amlodipine, and heparin. The plan is to extubate the patient today if he tolerates pressure support, and if not, a tracheostomy may be considered. Repeat CT chest will be ordered, and the patient will be weaned off the nasal cannula as tolerated. Sed rate and CRP are markedly elevated, indicating an inflammatory process. Rheumatology does not strongly believe that the patient's effusions are caused by underlying connective tissue disease.

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure. The patient has been off the ventilator for 24 hours and is comfortable. The patient's allergies include no known drug allergies. The patient has a history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, hypernatremia, dysphagia, and pericardial effusion. The patient is currently on heparin and metoprolol. The patient's review of systems is negative except for fatigue. The patient's physical examination is unremarkable except for poor dentition and the presence of a PEG tube. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 37.3C, heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure of 146/39 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on a nasal cannula. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, elevated creatinine, and elevated glucose levels. The patient's EKG shows atrial fibrillation. The assessment and plan include hypertension, hypotension, pleural effusion, respiratory failure, pericardial effusion, dysphagia, atrial fibrillation, and hypernatremia.
